subject: Fashion
title: Hippie Counterculture Dress
description: A 60-second lesson on Hippie Counterculture Dress.

hook.text: In 1967, 100,000 people gathered in San Francisco in tie-dye and flowers. Fashion became protest.

buildup.text: Hippies rejected mainstream fashion entirelyâ€”wearing handmade, secondhand, and non-Western clothing.

discovery.text: Borrowing from Indian, African, and Native American dress was meant as cultural appreciation.

twist.text: By 1970, major brands were selling mass-produced 'hippie' outfits. Rebellion got a price tag.

climax.text: Every counterculture gets absorbed by the market. The system sells your revolution back to you.

quiz.question: What happened to hippie fashion by the early 1970s?
options: It evolved into formal business attire for corporations
It was banned by governments as a public nuisance
Major brands mass-produced 'hippie' outfits, commercializing the rebellion
